item.feedback: This expression is used in the morning as well as in the afternoon.
This expression is mostly used by Muslims.
/SabaaH in-noor/ (lighted morning) is used to respond to /SabaaH il-Kheyr/.
/SaHa/ means health in general. /SaHtak/ is more specific, meaning your health.
/masaa in-noor/ (lighted evening) is the typical response to /masaa il-Kheyr/.
/keefak/ is used when speaking to a single person. For a group of people use /keefkon/.
/keefak intey/ is used only when asking a man how he is. /keefek intee/ is used when addressing a woman.
/nushkor/ means we thank. But this phrase is an exception to the rule and can be used to say I thank when only one person is speaking.
/ismak/ means your name and is used when addressing a man; /ismek/ is used when addressing a woman.
/ismee/ (my name) is used by both genders.
/HaSalee ish-sharaf/ can also be used instead of /tshar-rafna/.
/feek/ (to you) is used when addressing a man. /feekee/ is used for a woman and /feekon/ for a group.
This expression can be used at any time but at night you can also say /tiSbaH 'alaa Kheyr/.
/bshoofak/ (see you) is used when talking to a man. Say /bshoofek/ for a woman, and /bshoofkon/ when addressing a group.
When addressing a woman say /bshoofek/; use /bshoofkon/ for a group. /bshoofak/ (see you) is used when addressing a man.
